Setting up an evaluation procedure for choosing a threat intelligence platform (TIP) is a critical process that ensures you select the best solution for your organization's needs. Here's a structured approach to help you set up this evaluation procedure, starting with a Proof of Concept (POC) and followed by other essential steps:

: Clearly define what you need from a threat intelligence platform. This might include threat detection, integration with existing security tools, threat hunting capabilities, automation, and reporting.
: Develop a list of criteria based on your objectives. Criteria might include ease of use, quality and relevance of intelligence, integration capabilities, scalability, cost, and vendor support.
: Engage key stakeholders from different departments (e.g., IT security, compliance, risk management) to ensure the platform meets cross-functional needs.
: Research and shortlist vendors that offer threat intelligence platforms. Consider well-known vendors and emerging players to ensure a comprehensive evaluation.
: Collect detailed information about the platforms, including features, capabilities, case studies, and customer reviews.
Request for Information (RFI) / Request for Proposal (RFP)
: Send out an RFI or RFP to the shortlisted vendors to gather detailed information about their platforms. Include specific questions that align with your evaluation criteria.
: Assess the responses based on how well they meet your objectives and criteria.
Set Up a Proof of Concept (POC)
: Clearly define the scope of the POC, including the duration, specific use cases to test, and key performance indicators (KPIs).
: Set up a controlled environment where the POC will be conducted. Ensure that it closely mirrors your production environment.

: Develop specific scenarios or use cases that reflect your organization’s threat landscape. For example, test the platform’s ability to detect phishing attacks, monitor the dark web, or integrate with your Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system.
: During the POC, evaluate the platform based on:
: How easy is it to deploy and configure?
: How accurately does it detect relevant threats?
: How well does it integrate with existing tools and workflows?
: Is the platform user-friendly and intuitive?
: Quality of vendor support and availability of documentation.
: Gather feedback from the team involved in the POC to assess the platform’s strengths and weaknesses.
: Analyze the POC results using the KPIs defined earlier. This might include metrics such as detection rate, false positive rate, and time to deploy.
: Consider qualitative factors such as ease of use, vendor responsiveness, and overall user satisfaction.
: Create a comparison matrix to evaluate how each platform performed against the criteria. This can help in visualizing which platform best meets your needs.
: After the POC, request a more detailed demonstration from the top-performing vendors. Focus on any areas where you need further clarification.
: Conduct interviews with vendor representatives to address any outstanding questions and assess their long-term viability as a partner.
: Based on the POC results, demos, and interviews, select the platform that best meets your needs.
: Engage in contract negotiations with the chosen vendor, focusing on pricing, service-level agreements (SLAs), support, and any additional services.
: Before a full-scale deployment, consider a pilot phase where the platform is rolled out in a limited scope to ensure it performs as expected in a real-world environment.
: Use feedback from the pilot to make any necessary adjustments before full deployment.
: Proceed with the full deployment of the selected threat intelligence platform.
: Continuously monitor the platform's performance and ensure it evolves with your organization’s changing threat landscape.
: After full deployment, conduct a post-implementation review to assess the overall success of the project.
: Document lessons learned to improve future evaluations and deployments of similar technologies.
By following this structured evaluation procedure, you can ensure a thorough and objective selection process for a threat intelligence platform that aligns with your organization’s security needs.

Setting up a Proof of Concept (POC) to evaluate "Digital Shadows" and "Recorded Future" involves several steps. This process will help you assess which platform better aligns with your organization’s needs for strengthening threat intelligence. Here's a detailed guide to setting up the POC:
: Clearly outline what you want to achieve with the POC. For example:
Evaluate the accuracy and relevance of threat intelligence provided.
Test how well each platform integrates with your existing security infrastructure.
Assess the usability and efficiency of the platforms in improving your threat detection and response capabilities.
: Establish specific metrics and benchmarks that will determine the success of the POC, such as detection rate, false positive rate, ease of integration, and user feedback.
: Choose specific use cases that are critical to your organization's threat landscape. These could include:
: Assess how each platform identifies and provides intelligence on phishing campaigns.
: Test the platforms' ability to monitor the dark web for mentions of your organization or exposed data.
: Evaluate the capability to detect brand impersonation or misuse.
: Check how each platform profiles and tracks relevant threat actors.
: Ensure the use cases reflect real-world conditions and threats your organization might face.
: Set up a controlled environment where both platforms can be deployed simultaneously. Ensure this environment closely mirrors your production setup.
: Provide both vendors with the necessary access to your systems and relevant data to perform the POC. Ensure that data privacy and security protocols are strictly followed.
: Work with the vendor teams from Digital Shadows and Recorded Future to configure their platforms according to the specific use cases and goals of the POC.
: If integration with existing tools (like SIEM, SOAR, or other security platforms) is part of the POC, ensure this is set up correctly.
: Decide on a timeline for the POC, typically 2-4 weeks, to allow sufficient time to test all use cases and gather data.
: During the POC, closely monitor the platforms’ performance in real-time. Key aspects to observe include:
: How accurately the platforms identify threats and generate relevant alerts.
: Track the rate of false positives generated by each platform.
: Measure how quickly each platform identifies and reports on new threats.
: Assess the depth and relevance of the threat intelligence provided, including threat actor profiles, context, and actionable insights.
: Collect data on the key performance indicators (KPIs) set at the beginning. This could include:
User satisfaction and ease of use.
: Gather feedback from the team members using the platforms. This includes their experience with the platform’s interface, the usefulness of the intelligence, and any challenges faced during the POC.
: Compare the platforms based on the numerical data collected (e.g., detection rates, false positives). Use a scoring system to rate each platform against your success criteria.
: Consider user feedback, ease of use, and the quality of vendor support during the POC. This helps in understanding the practical aspects of each platform.
: Identify any potential risks or limitations associated with each platform based on the POC findings.
: Create a comparison report that summarizes the findings of the POC. Highlight the strengths and weaknesses of each platform based on the collected data and feedback.
: Present the findings to key stakeholders for their input. This includes discussing how each platform aligns with the overall threat intelligence strategy of the organization.
: Based on the POC results and stakeholder feedback, make a decision on which platform to move forward with.
: Share the POC findings with each vendor. This can also be an opportunity to address any concerns or request adjustments to their proposal.
: Once a platform is selected, negotiate the final contract terms, including pricing, service-level agreements (SLAs), and support levels.
: Develop a detailed deployment plan for the chosen platform, including timelines, resource allocation, and training for the security team.
: Consider starting with a pilot deployment before rolling out the platform organization-wide. This ensures any remaining issues are resolved in a controlled manner.

By following this structured approach, you can effectively set up and run a POC to evaluate "Digital Shadows" and "Recorded Future," ensuring that you select the platform that best enhances your company’s threat intelligence capabilities.

When setting up the POC, consider the following specific criteria to evaluate both platforms:
: Test how each platform performs in detecting and reporting on the specific threats relevant to your organization.
: Assess the ease of integration with your existing security tools and the ability to automate threat intelligence processes.
: Evaluate the user interface, ease of use, and the quality of reporting features.
: Measure how quickly and accurately each platform delivers threat intelligence and alerts.
: Analyze the relevance of the data provided, especially in the context of your industry and threat landscape.
: Consider the level of support provided during the POC and the ability to customize the platform to your specific needs.
: If your primary focus is on protecting your brand, securing your digital footprint, and managing risks from external threats, Digital Shadows may be more aligned with your needs.

: If you require a comprehensive threat intelligence solution that integrates deeply with your existing security infrastructure and provides broad threat coverage, Recorded Future could be the better option.
By thoroughly testing these aspects during the POC, you’ll be in a strong position to choose the platform that best enhances your organization’s threat intelligence capabilities.
